text: drive AI develops a fully autonomous car
platform to convert fleets of vehicles
into self-driving fleets based on a deep
learning first approach we're
approximately 90 employees and we're
growing so before moving to the cloud
our IT lahrman comprised of an in-house
server room and in the server room he
had a large storage cluster to store all
the amounts of data that our cars
collect in addition to a compute cluster
which contained CPUs and GPUs to run
various workloads some for deep learning
some for other kinds of CPU intensive
jobs data durability was one of our
business issues in order to manage
backups it's a harder task to do when
you're an in-house environment when
dealing with large amounts of data
everything must be done at a huge scale
bugs in the storage filesystem came up
and that caused issues for a team
whenever we wanted to expand hardware
capacity the process was lengthy and
arduous another thing was procuring
Hardware at the rate that we're scaling
it's difficult to keep up with developer
demands when we always need to purchase
additional hardware we heavily use
Amazon s3 for our storage solution we
also use Amazon's p2 and soon the p3
instances for our deep learning
workloads via auto scaling groups now
AWS allows us to provision temporary
resources at a very fast speed to meet
developer needs when we want to
accelerate a deep learning job we can
provision many temporary resources and
accelerate that job that's something we
weren't able to do in the past another
thing that it gives us is the ability to
scale our storage in a much more
seamless way
AWS allows us to do what we do best
building the brain behind the
self-driving car rather than focus on
building data centers we chose AWS
because they provide us with the compute
resources we need at competitive prices
and with excellent support
